review_title: $80 Christmas bonus yet higher ups get more than $2000 for doing nothing
pros: coworkers are the only pros at the workplace since they understand and share the cons of the workplace
cons: Worked hard during the afterschool program, made sure lesson plans were on time, took on more students than stated in ratio, and did more work in a 3-hour time frame compared to other jobs. Yet when Christmas came around I only received an $80 bonus to show for it. This is disrespectful and shows that they do not care about group leaders or youth workers who essentially run the program. The justification was since higher-ups get paid more they need a higher bonus relative to their paycheck. This pay disparity is disgusting, especially since the work they do is not challenging or meaningful in any way. But group leaders won't get a higher bonus because it means the higher-ups take a little pay cut on their overinflated salary and we can't have that. Avoid at all cost

job_title: Academic Tutor in New York, NY
pros: If you work specifically with Community Schools & in QT (not Aviation, can't speak for Aviation) I can say your experience will be good. Madeline is an amazing supervisor. Pay is also better. You can also accumulate sick hours even as part-time staff.
cons: Lack of hours, you have a maximum # you can work per week. On one hand, consistent work schedule & time for a second job. On the other, it's not viable in the long term unless you can switch positions.

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: - friendly staff - decent benefits - impactful work

pros: Fun environment. Friendly staff and fun job.

pros: Good staffing ratio compared to other companies

pros: My supervisors and upper management were very understanding and accommodating of my schedule and time needed to care for my terminally sick parent while i worked. I am so appreciative of that. The work itself is a pro because its aways good when you're assisting in the wholeness and well-being of another person.
cons: I felt that there were too many hands involved in the paperwork and areas of the position that required other department assistance. Sometimes one department has to go through another department to get approval and/ or t another person has to give paperwork to another person to sign or use and then give back to the first person etc. Things get delayed or overlooked in that process and it can be irritating over time, especially if there is only one or two people in that position taking care of a whole organization. I'm not use to that type of system and so i found myself frustrated often and i couldn't get used to it.

review_title: Values driven, connected services, larger scale means better systems

cons: More work still needs to be done on formal structured systems for employee compensation (this is being worked on currently).

pros: I worked here until about 2016. The only reason I stopped is because they weren't having the program that year.

review_title: Could have been better as expected
pros:
Met new friends, met parents, the kids were great, learned new skills.

Appreciated my work, I will miss everyone. Great moments here and there. I know other workers who had a blast (as in great moments).

We (as in all staff) put in all the effort 100% of the time. It was at least acknowledged in our meetings (which is great).

I was lucky to have great managers supporting me because I was in the right place, at the right time (before those great managers left)
cons:
Management always mentions  "budget cuts", which is not fair for the workers. We work hard, we should get a fair wage. 

And if someone doesn't like you, especially management -- you can be fired or released instantly, one way or the other (through legal matter; as in what the handbook states)

review_title: Great place to work.  Service to community and great corworkers
pros:
I have enjoyed working here.  The variety of programs is great and compared to many nonprofits there are important supports in place.  The fiscal team is super organized and helpful, HR is both fun and on-point, managers do their best to support staff.  There are good attempts throughout the year to bring staff together.  

People operating programs genuinely care about the people they serve and work well with their colleagues.
cons: Sometimes the pressures of service can be hard - some contracts have tough deliverables and we are not always fully staffed.  We really look forward to building renovations that will make spaces better.

review_title: A better job in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Sunnyside is a great place to grow and learn. Employees do have a chance to do creative things as well.
cons: The pay is good but don't expect to be promoted based on how hard you work. If you would like to make a career out of your job there, plan to stay in your applied position.

review_title: Worked there for 4 Years already but don't know what's next
job_title: Former Supervisor in Union City, NJ
pros:
I'm currently working at SCSS; here's the pros.

1) Great friends can be made here

2) Easy to adjust on your own, on some situations

3) Comfortable to start as in short-term work

4) Had amazing supervisors (at the time) who were brilliant in full assistance.

5) I got the best start in my career (going to say anonymously) from SCSS; without SCSS I would be having a hard time adjusting to other jobs; they really did help me in life.


As you can see, there's 5 pro's and con's for each, balances it out = 3 stars / decent.
cons:
Now the con's.

1) You have to know your IN's and OUT's from certain situations (off the bat)

2) Don't get too comfortable for the long term

3) Be careful what you say to others, as you can rub people the wrong way, intentional or not.

4) Some previous and current workers have personal addictions, I cannot say clearly what personal addictions they have, whether hard or soft -- but they are proud of what they do, illegal or legal at work or outside (cannot reveal full information; must be kept secret)

5) High turnover rate; from manager to coworker positions -- just bear in mind, not your fault, there's only so much you can do.


Numbers 4 & 5 can occur in every workplace, regardless of profession or positions; there's not much you can do, except drug test those individuals.


As you can tell, there's 5 pro's and con's for each, balances it out = 3 stars, not bad at all.
Every program has up's and down's.

pros: Sunnyside Community offers the ability to impact change and considers your ideas to use and supervisors are supportive.
cons: growth within organization is challenging. Employees keep the same title for years with little room to move.

pros: Great mission, dedicated staff, responsive & involved executives, generous vacation, and benefits. As with other non-profits, the workload is high and you're really expected to hustle. I like this because the fast-paced culture accelerated my development as a professional. My bosses really took the time to mentor me and were very generous about connecting me to professional development opportunities. I really felt like part of a community working here.
cons: The main admin office isn't the most beautiful space, but at least there are windows!

pros: Excellent work life balance. Generous vacation, personal and sick time. Good work environment. Negotiate good salary up front because once you start it's hard to get a raise.
cons: Limited growth opportunity as positions are directly connected to funding revenue. This is not much different than other non-profits, but still limit upward mobility.

pros: The coordinator is very organized, supportive and allows freedom to create and teach standard-based lessons. The work environment is friendly and positive.
cons: Being a relatively new program, they were yet to offer any full-time teaching positions. More teacher workspace at times would have been helpful.

review_title: Good place to re-calibrate, but don't get comfortable
pros: Good organizational mission, culture to match. Fair compensation. Good to go to and set your career outlooks up.
cons: Fairly high turnover rate for some roles, probably due to staff being overworked (or vice versa). Some offices are very cramped so there is a lot of hovering.

review_title: I do not recommend applying here.
pros: working with the kids
cons:
lack of opportunities 
poor management 
lack of growth 
refuse to promote those that show hard work and dedication and rather promote their "friends"

job_title: Adult ESOL Instructor in Sunnyside, NY
pros:
Easy location
Semi-motivated students
Most students are supposed to be there 
Easy to teach a class/design lesson week to week based on student interests
cons:
Like many agencies of its kind this suffers from unqualified staff, unprincipled directors and so the community programs do not serve those most in need but serve only to line the pockets of those scamming the DYCD for funding. 

The person in charge of youth services has an MA in poetry: no experience in public administration, no managerial savvy and zero communication skills. For someone who fancies they're "a writer" it's annoying trying to read their emails with poor grammar. Every time you ask a question or for clarification, the response is always, "I'm sorry I don't have the answer to that question." That is fine up to a point, but not when it's your job to know these things. Every time you catch this person out, they avoid eye contact and straight answers and you get three or four conflicting responses in the space of ten minutes. 

There is a lot of shady stuff going on, but in terms of fostering a collegiate atmosphere this is impossible with the supervisor hiring people without a teaching qualification, playing favorites and co-workers jockeying for position like it's a huge corporation, rather than a grass roots community non-profit. It's really sad because the students and clients who would most benefit are pushed into the background and left behind while so-called coordinators get pay rises. 

If you dare to advocate on behalf of the students or follow testing procedures by the book, you will be sent to HR like a naughty child, when all the while the bosses are corrupt and haven't got the slightest clue what they're doing. 

My predecessor jumped ship after two months. Now I know why! If you enjoy teaching, care about students, have an advanced degree (or two) I would warn you to stay well away and work in an academic setting, in higher education where those you work with are qualified, organized and respect and value you in kind.

review_title: extremely poor upper management / toxic and hostile work environment
pros: HR and its activities really try to improve employees spirits . vacation days and sick days are earned fairly quickly
cons:
the superiors are not trained to be effective leaders  nor capable of leading effectively . Programs get shutdown because employees quit due to the hostile/toxic work environment , valuable employees quit or get fired when they don't want to go along with illegal or unjust practices and labeled as " not team players" or " inflexible" because staff does not want to be flexible to shady practices of the higher ups.
 Higher ups are obsessed with numbers with no regard to the clients or the staff that is said to meet those numbers, so it leads to poor program quality time and time again and no hope for improvement 
you will never experience a program to be fully staffed because people don't stick around so expect to be over-worked or the company wants to cut corners and not hire enough people to deliver quality services

job_title: Home Health Aide in Sunnyside, NY
pros: Good for hours at your convenience.
cons:
Not good if you want a permanent case or steady hours. 
Unfortunately, the union (managed by a separate company) increased the threshold of part time qualification to 25 hours a week, instead of 20. This make securing a good case or the minimum number of hours much more difficult. Thus, disqualifying you from both insurance and union benefits.

Because of rapid expansion, space is an issue
